instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15‚Äù Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..
definitions.GPUVCORE_EN: What is GPUVCORE_EN? GPUVCORE_EN enables GPU VCORE when it is high, a power rail necessary for the GPU to function so you can get an image on the screen. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .

threads.title: 820 3332 No GPUVCORE
threads.message: 820 3332 No GPUVCORE, touched up the pins leads @ <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> twice, and reflowed the chip once. <SIGNAL>GPUVCORE_EN</SIGNAL> is also missing. No liquid damaged on board.

threads.title: 820 3332 No GPUVCORE
threads.message: Was the board already messed with. Missing <SIGNAL>GPUVCORE_EN</SIGNAL> is not something that happens normally.

threads.title: 820 3332 No GPUVCORE
threads.message: Board looks virgin to me Duke. If I understand this correctly <CHIP>U9100</CHIP> will not produce the EN signal, if it does not see the GPU, is that correct?

threads.title: 820 3332 No GPUVCORE
threads.message: Are you testing this with a known good screen attached?

threads.title: 820 3332 No GPUVCORE
threads.message: Yes, I have tested with the original screen, with my own known good screen, and measured vcore with no screen. is there a certain significance is there a certain significance to having a known good screen attached? Shouldn't GPUVCORE be present with or without a screen attached?

threads.title: 820 3332 No GPUVCORE
threads.message: i would try another <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> chip if you haven't yet. they can go bad.

threads.title: 820 3332 No GPUVCORE
threads.message: I replaced <CHIP>U8900</CHIP>, GPUVCORE is now restored, thanks fellas.
